author: James J.

description:
a beautiful place in a beautiful city.  
 It's a forest (complete with sun-filtering-through leaves and mysterious bush rustling), a perfect place to take a break (read a book, bring your journal, have a beer)
When it's a clear day and you can see straight to the Farallon Islands (home of the largest number of mature great white sharks, but you can't see 'em from the park) i doubt there is a more lovely spot.  
My favorite place in San Francisco.
author: Alexandra G.

description:
can remember the first time I walked to the top of Buena Vista Park. This park has to have the most stunning view because the walk alone is a hike. I definitely recommend that you wear your kicks when walking up this steep hill. When you finally do reach the top it is such a surreal experience; the vision is beyond anything I could ever imagine, for a hill, that is. You can see a good number of landmarks that have doted this city for many years. When you look to the north you see far beyond the beauty of the trees that surround this area. There is the most breath taking views of San Francisco to the Marin Headlands. From the west to the east you can see the Pacific Ocean to the San Francisco Bay and afar.

Buena Vista Park borders Haight Street between Buena Vista east and west and has multiple entrances. It is sited on a sand covered bedrock hill and has its own natural spring and steam. There are certain flowers and plants; for example, the coastal oaks flourish extremely well on this type of land. When I was adventuring around the park I thought WOW this is the absolute most amazing view hence the translation: good view. I never dreamed of a place that could have so many views while drawing emotions and thoughts too. I was so dazed I could see the oceans blue glare blend into the sky, church/temple(s), mountain range(s), infamous bridges and streets, and clusters of homes.

It is such a GOOD feeling to look around at what you have conquered so far in this extremely diverse city. Upon peeking out I always wonder why I moved to this city and what drew me here. Just taking one quick look brings back all the memories. It is nice to see where I fit in as an individual in this circle of life. I must also mention that there is a patch of grass to lay on and stare into the sky. It seems to me that many people do not know about this vastly rich park. A place where all of your cares and worries fade away. I felt like I was a child again, lying in the grass dreaming, thinking, and pondering.

Buena Vista is a different kind of park where you can rest or check out the views and the city. It is not that big but there is such a good energy about it! I recommend a trip there during morning hours and sunsets too! Some of my friends have watched the sunrise from there. It is a superior feeling I have after walking to the top, and when you look out over the City the feeling just gets better!
author: Tamara M.

description: Love this Park!!! So fun, calm, green! A peace sign shrub?! Kick ass! Come here to plan your revolution!
author: Twinstar G.

description: Stumbled upon this park on a gorgeous sunny spring day.  Beautiful gem of a park.  Next time will bring the doggies and take more time.
author: Michelle O.

description:
This is a great park that isn't too crowded, offers a lot of little trails for a variety of views, and gives you the feeling of being tucked away in the woods. There are a ton of hideaway spots (great for a daytime picnic or a nighttime mugging) in the overgrown bushes and under the tall trees so I wouldn't come here at dark by yourself and just be aware of your surroundings if you happen to be there at dusk.

If you tack Corona Heights onto your Buena Vista Park trek, you'll get fabulous views of the East Bay.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I will give this spot 5 stars because I grew up around the corner and actually used to play in the playground. 

Then I got older and we used to have Keggers up at the top of the hill
they never got busted.

I think the guys doin what they do @ night throw the cops off
author: Kim R.

description:
I haven't been to this park since my dog died.  I just went this morning for the first time in three years and remembered why I love it so.  

First of all, the park has AMAZING views of the city!  Secondly, it's just so tranquil and smothered in huge trees and bushes, that it's hard to not love it.  The many trails this park has and the high steps.  Make sure to wear your tennies or hiking boots to endure these steep inclines.  

I of course don't recommend any parks at night time, but during the day, rain or shine is fine!  May I recommend heading to this park when it's foggy and dewey.  It really makes for a very peaceful walk.  But, that could just be me.  Bring your dog for sure, the doggies love this place!!

Indeed you may have your homeless making house here sometimes, but they need shelter somewhere and I've never personally been bothered by anyone here, nor have I seen any needles like someone said.  

Love this park, nothing to hate about it really.  It truly is a gem in this amazing city!!
author: Kat M.

description:
I wish I made it to Buena Vista Park more often.   

It is really an amazing resource / retreat in the heart of the city.  A great walk with elevation to get a little exercise.  

Amazing views, large trees.  Especially pretty in Spring.

Somewhat unsafe at night though.
author: Bruce M.

description:
This is JUST for the tennis courts.  BVP gives me an overall uneasy feeling:  how many needles are in the bushes today?  will someone grab my ankles as I walk by?  will I see a couple engaged in a naked tango in the trees?

The tennis courts, however, are great.  Nice view of the city, well maintained courts and net, and close enough to my house to walk.
author: Krista C.

description: Great hour or two hike in a semi-wooded area. Good places to stop and look over the city. It's nice to interact with the dog owners and chit chat for a moment with total strangers.
author: Celeste T.

description:
This pretty hill is in close proximity to a number of cool SF neighborhoods/restaurants. So it's a perfect place to explore and work up an appetite before pigging out in the Haight, Cole Valley, Castro, etc. 

Watch out for just a few folks who might be waking up or bunking down for the night.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Beautiful views of San Francisco are even better after walking up a steep hill... there are a few trees in the way, but hey, that's nature!

I looove going up this park while walking towards Haight St... it makes me feel like I've accomplished something that day :)
author: Laura W.

description:
This is just for the gardeners/landscape caretakers at Buena Vista Park.... I applaud you! You manage to keep this park looking pretty good given its high traffic volume all day and all night. You also are taking some health risks as mentioned in other reviews, it's not rare to find needles, human poop (so much worse than dog poop, also found there) and condoms.

I have a dog walking business and often walk my "pack" there. The gardeners are extremely tolerant because I think, thankfully, the majority of us dog walkers have developed a respect for them and their work and we do our best to keep our dogs well behaved and staying out of areas being propagated. 

As a dog walker, I feel at peace in this park and not like I'm a criminal like I do in so many other parks in this city, thanks mostly to the gardeners at BV! :)
author: Keri R.

description:
Boy I would not want to be here alone in the dark but on a clear evening, with two tennis courts, blackberry vines to be picked and views of the entire city - where else would I want to be? 

With other green space such as the panhandle, Alamo Square and Golden Gate Park all in close proximity,  Buena Vista is perfect when you want privacy and romantic views.
author: Jessica M.

description:
This review is just for the tennis courts.

Like others have said, the two courts are a little less than stellar - probably resurfaced sometime in the mid-late 1990s.  After it rains, one of the courts tends to puddle up with water.  And Saturday/Sunday mornings can be pretty busy....

But, the view is pretty amazing - you can look over Dolores Park, Downtown SF, and even the bay.  If you do want to play on Sat/Sun mornings, I suggest arriving at 8:30am or 8:45am; otherwise you may have a 30+ minute wait (sitting on some benches), while the courts turn over.  Outside of that, the weekday and weekend afternoons are typically clear.  And I must add that some of the cutest dogs come walking by...

In terms of safety, I can see why people are concerned.  There are probably 15 paths that lead to the courts, but only 2 are actually paved.  Try to enter off Haight, and work your way up the stairs and to the South/SouthEast, and you should be golden.  There isn't a great entrance off Buena Vista, unless you like a quick, steep hike up through some dirt and dry trees/shrubs.

So stop reading and go play some tennis!  Oh, and maybe save an old tennis ball for those super-cute dogs that walk by.
author: ashok r.

description: Amazing views of the city. Be sure to stop near the bottom and jump on a swing for another fun view of the city.
author: Vicki L.

description:
I heard some shady things about this park, so I usually walk around it on my way from my house to the Haight, but this weekend we wanted to walk through the park as we are still committed to our walking trips around San Francisco.

We walked straight through it and I must say I was really impressed.  Suddenly you are out of the city and in nature.  It really is much denser than I thought.  It would be a fun place to walk around and explore.

When we got to the top we had a great view of San Francisco!  

I think this park is totally worth-while.  I take off one point because the boards that are there to make stairs actually make it more difficult to walk around.  Besides that it's a cool little spot and I didn't see any of those shady things people spoke about.
author: Sean O.

description:
uh uh uh OMG was that guy getting a bl** job in the bushes?!
Guess the tweekers are jealous. Hence the beatings.
Avoid at night. Thought would be a good short cut to the car after a home party.
author: miriam b.

description:
A pretty little thing like me wouldn't dare wander through all the nooks and crannies at night, although I am definitely not the target night time market, I'm not about to tempt the gods. 

But, during the day time, this is a dirty urban utopia. As I feel the burn on the back of my thighs as I brave the hills or the steps if I'm lacking patience that day I watch my view get better and better. As I explore off path I see reminders that tell me baby, you're still in the city. Tall cans and hot pink condoms (way to be safe boys), various articles of clothing, trees, flowers, trunks filled with rocks, city to the right, elements to the left. I'll charge those steps like a retired Rocky. I know that view up at the top ain't going no where, not without me, oh no.

Seedy it may be, but BVP is one of my favorite places for urban exploration.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Ok, we get the idea, don't go to this park after dark.  Seriously, what woodsy, unlit park *would* you go to after dark?

Personally I think this park is beautiful.  It's really the closest of the hill parks to downtown, so the views are unbeatable.  Plus the tree cover is quite atmospheric, especially the cypress trees.  When the fog rolls through here it's hard to believe that the heart of the city is so close.  And I really don't recall seeing that many "park people", certainly not as many as the east end of GGP.  

Also, if you're walking through here, take the time to walk through the hilly neighborhoods surrounding the park as well.  You'll be drooling with envy over the gorgeous houses and views.
author: Wes M.

description:
Nice park, pretty views.  The stairs kicked my butt, but I'm pregnant and had my toddler in a hiking pack.  I was worn out to say the least.  

The top was kind of anti-climatic. It's got good views but it's all still partially blocked by trees (or at least from what I saw.)  I may have missed something but by the time I got up there, I was too tired to explore much.

My dog loved it.  I'll probably be back when I'm not carrying two babies.

Oh, and the top grassy knoll area smells like dog pee... so I wouldn't sit down (or if you take a picnic, take a blanket too.)
author: Leah M.

description:
Thank you Buena Vista Park! You are single handedly getting my buns into shape with all your uphill trails! You are my only defense against all the decadent, cream sauce covered, meals that I keep eating in local restaurants.

I love you almost as much as my dogs do.  They've now taken to faking the need to go potty, just so that they can go outside and pull on their leashes in the direction of your green, tree covered hills.

I have decided to completely ignore/overlook/pretend its a rumor that there are creepy trolling men looking for a little booty action love in your bushes. That's why I go during the day, stay on the path, and avoid eye contact with anyone  whose hands are not clearly visible.

I love the view from the top of the hill. And I love when the professional dog walkers bring their troop of happy pups up there to frolic.  

Buena Vista is my own little slice of nearby heaven
author: Melissa J.

description: This is nice park with a lot of uphill paths/steps and when you reach the top it's a dog area and you get a nice view as well. Would like to take a nice leisure walk through here again and take photos.
author: Helen L.

description: The view from the top of the hill reminds me why people love living in the City and why the rest of us Bay Areans like to brag about living in one of the most beautiful regions in the world. Why have I never walked (hiked, really) through this park before. I always pass by it when riding the 71 Muni, but never gave it a second thought. What a (hidden) gem! Climb to the top! It's worth it. The view is outstanding especially on a clear day. Like Naomi K., I would totally come here to escape any chance I got if I lived in the City. Just lovely.
author: Farah S.

description: This park would be better if there weren't so many derelicts living there.
author: Roger H.

description: You know it's quite amusing to read reviews of some of these postage stamp sized parks in towns in the peninsula as if they're Wonderland. Now here's Buena Vista Park (I call it Buena Vista Social Park), which is a tiny fraction of the size of Golden Gate Park or the Presidio... And it's a breathtaking wonder. Giant old growth trees. Lovely spiraling trails. Quaint stairs in the hillsides. And of course spectacular views. Oh, and plenty of free street parking. Yup. Every time I go to the Safeway on Market Street I stop here and take a lil hike first. Five stars easy.
author: Chuck S.

description:
This is the kind of place that makes me feel special for getting to come here every morning with my dog.  If you go in the morning, the sunlight filters through the trees, and it's an ethereal, magical sight.   Also, you feel really great if you hike all the way to the top, there's a great view of Golden Gate Bridge.

Note:  The SouthWestern slope is currently closed off for construction, and it won't be finished until October-November.

One star taken off for all the junkies, though they've never really bothered me, especially since I own a huge, vicious-looking dog.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I live right on this park and it is a beautiful park during the day, but it is totally sketchy at night.  I wake up in the middle of the night and look out my window and see creepy looking people walking in and out of the park.  Lots of rampant rumours about what goes on after dark and I'm not so sure it is all rumour.

It is a really big park, if you look at the Google maps of it, there are tons of walking trails.  The playground is always empty and great for younger kids.  The tennis courts never seem to be in use and you can easily street park in the area if coming from afar.

It is either the oldest park in SF, or the first one, can't remember.
author: Doug M.

description:
A gorgeous little oasis in the city, with one of the best hills to climb. The views from the top and from the lookout point are amazing and you can usually see the Golden Gate Bridge.

We live a few blocks from the park, and we take our dog there every day because he loves it so much. Lots of trails, squirrels to chase, grass to roll on.

Minus one star for the fact that often the people that illegally camp here will use the park as their personal bathroom.
author: PF D.

description:
Great place to bring your dog, but stick to the designated trails, don't make the mistake and try to cut through the "MAN" made trails... You'll find that oh so uncomfortable situation of some dude looking for dude on dude on dude on dude on dude on dude on dude action. 

So that is why you get 2 stars you dirty little park. Unless you're into dude on a lot of dude action and the high possibility of contracting an angry STD, then you can give it 5 stars... get a room... for real real, not for play play.
author: danny e.

description: This is an impressive spot, especially once you learn its history and all that went into establishing the park.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Fantastic views let you have a vigorous yet relaxing walk.

It gets really dark in evening, so be careful after sunset though.
author: Chacha M.

description:
Once, I had some friends in from out of town, and it was a beautiful Sunday afternoon. I was taking them down to Haight, cause they'd never been there, and it was in the area. 

On our way there, my girlfriend suggested we walk up this park. It's very beautiful here, but kinda rough walking when you have a buzz going. Plus, I think I saw some one shitting in the bushes. Nice.
author: Matthew S.

description:
The thing about this park is that one must never venture past the grassy knoll that faces Haight Street.  You may encounter a crusty hippie who has been residing there since he got kicked out of Golden Gate Park in 1972 or find some cracked out 14-year-old from Fresno who will try and beg some fries or pizza out of you.
I went out there for a day of walking around the Haight with my roommate from New York and we stopped to sit and watch the cars go by.  We were thoroughly entertained by this absolutely unassuming dude who looked like he had a corporate day job and a wife and kids in some subdivision in Daly City.  He had this contraption that made thunder sounds and he sang songs along with the rolling thunder claps.  Then he started talking about eBay and what you can find on it.

"Man, you could buy a dragon for sure on eBay.  I want a dragon man.  One that could swoop down and you wouldn't have to feed it or nothing.  Don't have to worry about fossil fuels.  I'm gonna get me a dragon, man"

When he got tired of talking about eBay, he moved on to talk about the CDs he bought at Amoeba, namely Prince and the new Justin Timberlake (which he referred to as "Justin Timberland").  

"Man, I love Prince.  He's got the jams.  You play that shit for your lady and daaaaamn!  That Justin Timberland, man, I don't really know about him (thunder clap)."

Some people were sitting close to him and started giggling, which egged him on.  After they made fun of him for professing his love for Toni Braxton ("...and I will never even breathe again!") he threw the Justin Timberland CD at them and went back to talking about a dragon.

Of course, he was talking to no one in particular.  I always have a good time at the grassy knoll when I want to stop for a ciggy or two and people watch.  Good times.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Good views and big trees.
Maybe not so nice at night --
Watch out for condoms.
author: Mike W.

description:
As stated by many, great views at the top hence the name. Stick to the top and perimeter to avoid the possible views of gay folks puttin on a show - in broad daylight!  C'mon fella's get a room.  

A great place for banana slug watching.
author: greg e.

description: This park is surrounded by beautiful homes (one I saw up for sale at 2.1 mil! I'm starting to save now). When you walk into the park it's like you're not in San Francisco anymore, more like Oregon or something. The woods are dense with trails winding through, up and down, throughout the whole park. The best part comes when you reach an opening and you remember that you actually are still in San Francisco. The views are amazing! At one spot you can actually see the tippy top of the Golden Gate Bridge (on a clear day of course). Beautiful park, great to bring your dog for a nice hike.
author: Casi C.

description:
I love hills and stairs and great views, so I love this park. I don't go at night, but then, you really wouldn't want to go ANYWHERE in this city that has heavy foliage at night - no idea what you might find. 

Interesting note: this park was built. It is man-made. And if you look at the drains along the paths, they are actually marble. Marble with names and dates on them . . .yup, they are old headstones from a cemetery. 

Happy Trails!
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
I think it all depends on what day you visit this park.  Take last Saturday for example...75 degrees, a comfortable breeze, and not a cloud in the sky.  The views from the top terraces offered amazing 360 degrees panoramic views of the city.  It was relatively quiet (not including the incessant sound of sirens - sounded like the entire outer Richmond was burning) and their was a really pleasant smell - a slight hint of fresh cut grass.  

That said, I could see why it would not be as pleasant to visit, say at night, esp. alone.  Lots of places for people to hide and conduct illicit activities.  Go during the day with friends and enjoy what a city park can offer.
author: Sy K.

description:
So today happened to be one of those rare beautiful days in SF, with clear blue skies, temps in the high 60s and SUN!!!  I think to myself, today is a perfect day for a picnic lunch and reading in the park.  I pack up my book, blanket and shades and head out the door to explore an unfamiliar region of the city. I am picturing lying in the grass, drinking an iced coffee, enjoying the sun.  To my dismay, you will not find any of this at BV park!!!!

I parked along Haight and climbed the over hundred something stairs, along a thickly wooded dirt path to discover: a single park bench facing a partially obstructed view of the city.  No grass, no sun, not the best view I've seen.  Furthermore, I spent the entire hike up feeling like I needed to be watching over my shoulder for some cracked out mass murderer-pepper spray in hand.  

Lessen learned: unless you are a six foot something Dad with boys looking for an adventure or a young woman with a death wish- avoid this park at all costs.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Very cool park... it's all woodsy and stuff!  Who could tell that there is a kiddie playground and tennis courts from where I was standing on Haight Street?  I trod all around it today and finally found some of the fragments of Victorian tombstones that line the gutters of the park.  whoa.

It's not a park that I will hang out in regularly, but I'm glad it's there and when I want to raise my blood pressure a bit I'll power walk to the top.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Only two courts here, one has a crack in it, so if the ball hits it - who knows what funny bounce it might take... NOT COOL, if  you're in the middle of a game and a bunch of people are watching.

The other court has a dip in it, so water gathers there. NOT COOL.

The only saving grace to these courts are the views of the city, but you should be watching the ball instead, right? Right.
author: wayne s.

description: I love parks!  But particularly this one.  It's small, but still can make you feel like you are in the middle of the woods.  The views are really good as well. I added some pictures of both, it's just amazing.  Don't go in there by yourself at night.  I have hiked up and watched the sunset and the sunrise both from the top and loved it.  I do that with a group or at least one friend generally.
author: Heidi P.

description: On a sunny afternoon, Buena Vista Park is the perfect place to chill out, drink a beer, and smoke a nice bowl. Ahhh yes...very nice. It also makes a great spot to pee when walking home at wee hours in the morning after pulling an all nighter.
author: Danielle K.

description: Hiking around the curvy trails and wooden steps of Buena Vista park is an enjoyable way to spend a sunny San Francisco afternoon. Views of city can be glimpsed through tall hillside trees and sweet smelling flowers.  Patches of grass and park benches randomly decorate the landscape, and offer a perfect place to enjoy the sights or a  delicious picnic. Bring your best friend, boyfriend, or adorable dog for an easy afternoon exploring the trails and enjoying a "Buena Vista".
author: Caroline J.

description:
A is for AWESOME VIEWS at the top of the hill
B is for the tennis BALLS you can whack around on the courts that are almost never in use
C is for CRUISING, which if you're gay, a man and horny, you can do in the bushes
D is for DRUGS, which you can also do in the bushes, just mind the men having fun and don't disturb too much!
E is for EXERCISE - you'll get yours by climbing the hill to get to the views
F is for FECKING, which, again, you can readily happen upon when chasing after your dog into the trees to see where he dropped a poop. 
G is for  GRASS, which you will find on the north side of the park, both in the form of the green stuff people golf on as well as the kind you can buy in baggies from some smelly guy on the corner by the steps. Warning: the second "grass" may be "oregano" and the "smelly guy" could be a "police officer." 
H is for HORNY - I mentioned the cruising, right?
I is for ILLUMINATED - which is the amazing spectral of USF's spires seen lit up from this park at sunset
J is for JOGGING, which you can do if you're motivated (*mind the dog shite!)
K is for KLANSMEN, which you won't find here
L is for LESBIANS SUNTANNING NAKED, which you also are not likely to find here (Michigan Womyn's Festival = better shot)
M is for MUTTS, which run aplenty on the trails
N is for NIGHTTIME, which is a sketchy time to visit the park (unless you're into that sort of thing and have already hit the Windmills, Collingwood, the last car of BART, Lafayette Park, the second floor men's room, 2nd stall, of SF's main library and SFM4M on AOL)
O is for OUT OF TOWNERS, who you're unlikely to encounter here
P is for POPPERS, which have been done here
Q is for QUIET, which is the silence of the hill
R is for REHAB - there's one conveniently located on the North West side of the park
S is for SILENCE, another term for quiet (see what I did there? You thought I was going to say "sex," but I didn't!)
T is for TENNIS - again, best kept super secret courts in town
U is for UGGH, I'm getting bored of this alphabet
V is for VIRUSES, which can be caught by the dozen (again, watch the dog crapola)
W is for WATER, which you can just almost see from certain vistas
X is for XERXES, which is mentioned in the movie "GO!" and has nothing to do with this review, except that it's a great movie
Y is for YERBA BUENA, which sounds like BUENA VISTA, but isn't: YB has a playground, bowling and ice skating, BV has dogs, tennis and views
Z is for ZIPPER, which you don't want to get caught with yours down taking a whiz and not knowing the kind of attention that can signal in this park...

One of the best places to walk your dog in the city because there are short trails through trees and a good hike to the top of the hill. You are so unlikely to be busted having your dog off-leash here. Also, great for tennis, since most yuppies shun the place due to cruising and drugs. Great, well kept secret awesome spot.
author: Hannah Q.

description: Its perimeter is lined with an eclectic collection of apartment buildings and private homes (one owned by actor Danny Glover) that proves San Francisco is as diverse in its architectural styles as it is in its population. As previously noted, the views from the top are phenomenal on those days when this section of the city isn't shrouded in fog. For a period of time, a series of severe gay bashings drawing limited police response kept thrill-seeking men out of the bushes at night, but apparently the little rascals have returned in full force. Heavy overgrowth and underbrush contribute to its viability as a spot to deal drugs, as well.  As dangerous at night as it is beautiful by day, so definitely proceed with caution after dark.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Yeah...I am gonna say it...I admit I have...been to the park and um...done things....oh well you only live once...oh and when I stood up I had dirty knees :-)
author: Denny R.

description:
beauty.  fog.  wind.  that deep woodsy odor.  kid-friendly playground. headstones in the paths.  short cuts straight UP.   bums.  crusiers. dogs!

This sweet stunning park is a jewel by day - beware after dark.

Hint: the view from the tip-top is so-so, but the outcrop to the East of the summit is best.  Bring a windbreaker!
author: Jim S.

description: Buena Vista Park is a gem! Despite it's central location, it's always pretty empty and quiet, plus it has a dog run and tennis courts. But the best parts about it are the incredible views from the top (360 view of the city) and the fact that there are over 3200 trees in the park!
author: Sara W.

description: The oldest park in San Francisco is one of my favorites.  I've actually never walked all the way up to the top, but I do enjoy reading on the lawn facing Haight Street when it's warm enough.  The grass can be kind of sketchy, and there will be some strange people around, but I've found that the street people on this part of Haight Street aren't as demanding as their counterparts west of here.
author: John S.

description: what a gorgeous park! you'll work up quite a sweat climbing to the top, and once you get there, wowweeee! it's gorgeous. views of the city all around. such a killer spot to pack a picnic and sip on a brewski.
author: cristina s.

description: One of my (and my dog's for that matter) favorite walks in the city is circling up through the park to the top.  With all the trees, you literally get engulfed in the park.  When you reach the top, you are treated to one of the most amazing panoramic views of the city, bay, and on especially clear days the farallon islands in the pacific.
author: eugene c.

description:
beautiful views. we walked up and down many of the paths, and saw striking views of the west end of san francisco. the sun was setting, so that added to the splendor.

one note: if you don't like the cold, then bundle up. the wind really slams the park, and without hats our ears were freezing within 20 minutes.
author: omar k.

description: Great place to make out in the daytime. Steer clear of the stinky hippies and crackheads. I used to not like the park so much because when I first moved to SF and mosied by, there was a dead guy in the bushes right on Haight St and the cops were just standing around sipping coffee and letting everyone get a good look, I didn't need to see that. I'm sure there's been lots of dead bodies in places I've been so I refuse to let those experiences stop me.
author: Colleen B.

description: Pretty good as far as in-city dog parks goes.  Great trails and big trees make it fun for dogs to run around and nice to get a break from city life.  The walk to the top is a nice short hike and you can enjoy a nice lunch on grassy area with beautiful city views. The drawbacks: there are a lot of dog walkers with up to 12 dogs and lots of dirty, vocal hippies hanging around near Haight street that have aggressive, un-neutered dogs.
author: Angie K.

description: On a clear day this month I finally climbed the mountain!  This was the original Divisadero, Spanish for "lookout."  Great views between the trees.  The City looks smaller and hillier up there than I expected.  I was able to spot my home (who doesn't try that?).  Good views of the Pacific Ocean and the East Bay.  Climbing through the trees has a very calming effect.  The park was uncrowded, the birds were having fun, and the trails looked like they were being maintained for the most part.  There's pavement in there, and once we found that we stuck to it.  Walking back down the stairs to Haight Street had an otherworldly feeling.
author: David D.

description: I love this place!  It's like a nature hike in a forest but in the middle of the city, and it's not crowded in the interior.  It's quite lovely and almost peaceful.  Minus 1 star for some slightly creepy people here and there, occasional litter, graffiti and loitering teens.
author: I. Lee W.

description: This was the site of my first mushroom trip. At the time I thought it was a beautiful place in a kind of sketchy way and that I was never going to be normal again. I thought it was just the effects of the fungus but years later I realized I was right on both counts
author: Josua P.

description: Requires a hike from home, so that I have earned my park-bound laziness. This is one of the more beautiful and interesting parks in the city, and is surprising in size and is quite quiet.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I used to go to Buena Vista park almost daily with my last dog.  I loved it because I could hike around and my dog loved it because of the smells, the pine cones, and most of all the squirrels.  It's a good work out and great exercise for your dog.  The views at the top are INCREDIBLE, especially on a sunny and clear day.  Even though it's in the middle of the city it doesn't feel like you are.  Unfortunately, there are a few things I didn't like about this park:

1)  The muzzled Akita, with a dog walker, who attacked my dog and punctured her cornea by smashing her muzzle into my dog's eye.  

2)  The ziploc bags of condoms and lube hanging from tree branches.

3)  My dog once led me down a path and we arrived at a tree with writing on it directing us to "young hung men"...the problem is the arrow was pointed the same direction as all the squirrels!!!  

4)  Another time my dog ran excitedly ran into the bushes (on the side of the main cement path, I might add) because she heard some rustling and two men quickly ran out of the bushes pulling up their pants, that was awkward to say the least.    

5)  There's poop and used toilet paper on the ground.  If I have to pick up my dog's poop then people should have to pick up their poop and properly dispose of it in a trash receptacle, should they decide to go outside on the ground.
author: Jessica C.

description: As much as I love that this park is near me, has great views and lots of trails, I can't get over it's appearance. In so many places it just looks so run down and dirty; it's not kept up well at all. Walking around and especially uphill is worth it though!
author: Barbs J.

description: Don't let this place fool you. From the outside it looks like a simple trail with trees covering it, but as soon as you start walking you're going to have to choose whether you want to walk on the steep cement path or walk up the stairs that seem to lead to nowhere. I came here with my cousin after eating pizza and was not properly dressed for the hike, so I recommend some good running or hiking shoes. The only down side I can think of are the homeless that live hidden in the bushes, but then again a park isn't a park without homeless.
author: Gabby H.

description: A great place to take your dog for a hike in the city! There are plenty of trails (paved and unpaved) that wind up, down, and around the park. You and your pooche will have fun getting lost in the tree cover. I have noticed some EXTREME sketchiness on the North East end of the park (near Duboce St). If you follow the trails just above the sidewalk that surrounds this part of the park, you may notice pockets of weird men standing in the bushes. They always seem startled when my dog and I are walking through. I don't know if this is a place for gay sexual favors or a place to get drugs. Either way I'd suggest avoiding this part of the park.
author: Sal B.

description: Amazing views. Even though there is no leash law enforcement I wasn't able to unleash my dog as she's not the brightest of creatures. Might be my favorite park in SF...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Awesome place to go for a jog. Wind up the hill and if can reach the top...props. Great views from unsuspecting places. Agreed about some of the sketchy characters that inhabit this place. Women should avoid this place after dark. Gay men apparantly love it because the tennis court at the top is a notorious place to hook up discreetly. Why do I know these things? I guess you can't live in SF without knowing more about gay people than gay people do. This park is great but if you're looking for sun and fun go to Dolores. If you're looking for a good workout dodging crackheads then this is your place.
author: Steve H.

description: What to do.  What to do.  I live EXTREMELY close to this park.  On the one hand, I'm proud and would like to sing its praises.  On the other, I don't want too much riff raff stomping down the trails.  I also feel that it is my civic duty to warn people about the seedier elements of this place - trust me, you DO NOT want to be walking around this place at night (unless you have a vicious animal to protect you, or, better yet, Captain Planet - cause he's our hero, gonna stomp pollution down to zero).  Ahh, f-it.  This park deserves its name.  The view IS beautiful.  Just bring your can of mace if you go after dark.  But stay off the tennis courts!  They're mine!
author: Jason S.

description: truly a great SF treasure, Buena Vista is a great civic jewel that shines brightly from its upper Haight perch.  A true multi-use park that gets joggers, walkers, trippers, dog walkers, tennis players, guide book hikers, toddlers at the playgrounders, picnics at the toppers, not quite ready for sleep and looking for gay sexers, cops on motorcycles looking to bust the having sexers, and everything in betweeners.  never a dull moment and usually a great view from  the Marin headlands and the top of the Golden Gate, to the Mission to Twin Peaks to SBC Park to Corona Heights to, well, you get the panoramic picture, dont you?  Well?  the tennis courts have literally million dollar views.  the unpaved trails look like an Ewok village.  great park, folks.
author: church B.

description:
had some scary experiences here on halloween a couple of years ago. first of all, i wasn't in my right mind at the time and we were a little bit paranoid/nervous since we were there at like 3am on halloween and lots of strange people were everywhere (at least i think they were) also, at the top of the park...i swear we walked in on a circle jerk which was really disturbing at the time. as well it shoudl be, i imagine. 

anyway, i'm sure it's a really nice park in real life, but my experience there just gives me the heeby jeebies just thinking about it.
author: annie c.

description: Just look at the view in the photograph. This big hill probably has some of the best views of San Francisco outside of the office buildings downtown. But you'd rather be here than in one of those offices.
author: Anonymous P.

description: well-kept gem of a park with beautiful views.  go in the middle of the day and meet every dog walker in the tri-county area.
author: Sasha R.

description: The tennis courts here are, like, the best in public courts.  First of all, each has it's own cage so you won't be hitting balls into other courts.  Second of all, they are rarely crowded.  And finally, they are at the top of the park and have a splendid view.
author: T-Bone L.

description: As my favorite hill 2 blocks from my house, Buena Vista Park has got it all.  Ass-kicking stair climbs; a lovely, sort-of well lit sometimes creepy road that makes me run a little faster once the sun goes down; amazing views from all around; tennis courts; a playground that can be fun to venture into at night; the Haight Street wanderers and their dogs; and, from what I hear (though thankfully not literally) plenty of eager men looking for some lovin, and um views?...  I love living near here - the loop is my favorite place to blow off steam from a frustrating day downtown.
author: Nicole C.

description: Great views of the city.  I wandered into the park off Waller Street while walking around Haight Ashbury one afternoon -- it was just the little woodsy escape from the city streets that I needed.  Also park provides a shortcut, albeit steep downhill, into Duboce Park area and Church Street/Market Street shopping area.
author: Ed M.

description: This park has a wild quality to it that can be very beautiful and fun to explore.  I'm slightly scared of it though and wouldnt wander here by myself after dusk.
author: b s.

description: Love it!  The views are stupendous.  Day or night, rain or shine...this park has attitude.
author: Elan D.

description:
even though it is a short, non-exhausting climb to the top of the hill, the view is clear especially on a bright, blue day. if you're ever to be walking around aimlessly, then buena vista is surprisingly close to corona heights, so visit that hill also. 

one time i was walking to buena vista with a group and a gardener told us that the gutters on the side of the trails are lined with tombstones from the cemetery on masonic and geary [when masonic and geary WAS a cemetery, way back when...] evidence of the tombstones are that not all of them are print-side facing the dirt, so some of the tombstones display lettering... and the text is pretty interesting. searching for tombstones with print facing up is a nice treasure-hunting game if you're every wandering in buena vista.
author: Court L.

description:
the views are really beautiful but it's kinda dirty .
and you smell like dog/cat pee afterwards.
author: Angeline Y.

description: I've heard a lot of horror stories of vampires in the bushes sucking loudly for a liquid reward... oh wait, vampires or gay guys? I can't remember.
author: Quartknee K.

description: what a dump. a haven for drug addicts and sexual deviants after dark. during the day you will see unbathed hairy people, throwbacks or timewarpers from 1967. the only positive note was the time I peed by the stairs on Buena Vista East. I hope a hophead slipped on it
author: Prima D.

description: it's a nice workout to walk to the top of this park and the view is really nice from there.  it took a good 15 to 20 minutes to reach it.  i was all sweaty, but seeing the city below and the golden gate bridge from there was well worth it.  i wouldn't wander through here when it gets dark, as there were some shady characters in the bushes on a few of the paths.
author: Immer E.

description:
To call this place a "park" is perhaps a misnomer... more like a scrubby peak in the midst of the city, criss-crossed by haphazard trails. There are trails that make you feel lost in a good way; slightly bewildered, out of the ordinary loop, outside the well-trodden paths and leave you feeling flushed with your own sense of adventure and youthful ability to still surprise yourself and to break away from comfortable routes.
Not this place.
Although I walked up here in the middle of the day in the company of a strong partner, it did not surprise me to read warnings from other yelpers about not coming here alone or at dusk.
This place is frankly creepy, and with very little to offer to off-set the danger quotient. A bunch of poorly-maintained scrubby overgrown dusty trails climbing up, up, up, to.... nowhere. A little patch of grass at the top with OK vistas. Nothing to write home about. Not to mention, the creep factor. Did I mention the creep factor? Sleeping bags and makeshift campsites littered the hillside. 
The next time I want to climb a bunch of slippery steps to nowhere while looking over my shoulder to make sure I'm not being followed, I'll make sure to find my way back here.
Or I could just go to a really nice park.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
this place is vile. i imagine the cops decided to let the bums and addicts have this park in exchange for not setting foot in golden gate and bothering the tourists. seems to have worked, since this place is littered with them and golden gate harbors those high class ones with a broken down RV. Buena Vista park is like the TL with trees. crackheads, heroin addicts, illicit sex, etc. 

and for all those who say the view is great, take a walk over to corona heights, where it's relatively clean and serene. and the view is better.
author: Saikat P.

description: this is a cute little park to stomp through after a hectic day of window shopping in haight (seriously, i ain't about to drop $20 on a mousepad!?). there are a lot of dogs roaming about so keep your mace out. just kidding! but, if you plan on taking a breather to enjoy your pb&j sandwich, watch out for lurking doggs. there are some nice views of the city from up here.
author: Diane A.

description: peaceful, beautiful views, mellow. but beware the cruising after dark! and the werewolves (just kidding, kinda).
author: T O.

description: Played tennis here today.  We had to wait about a half an hour until we got a free court.  But it was ok because while we were waiting we met three cool new people. And we met this guy who felt compelled to tell us these stories of when he used to play with his buddies back in the 60's.  He said he was "really good" and was the best "in the state of...the state of...(insanity)...California."  He told us he moved up from playing there, at Buena Vista, to..Golden Gate park.  Wow, that made us smile.  He also told us, though, that all his friends have since died and that he is scared.  He looked ravaged.  We didn't know quite how to respond.  He just wanted to talk.  Well, the place has a history that you can feel.  Surrounded by the city, on a clear day, you feel like you are in a special place.  At least, I did.  I had never been here prior to today.  I felt lucky to have been here this afternoon.  A Buena Vista, indeed it has!
author: Lauren S.

description: i love this urban park. i hike from the lower haight all the way up to the very top with my dog, and let me tell you, my ass cheeks are tighter for it. man, those stairs are a killer, but it's great cardio. you can take the long windy road up or take the stairs, but either way, you'll feel the burn. i might be an idiot, but it took me like a year to find my way around this park. there are so many paths, both paved and wooded, and nooks and homeless camps to stumble upon. minus one star because my dog occasionally stumbles upon poopy gifts left behind by homeless campers, and she loves eating shit. this means i have to wash her mouth out because i don't want diseases or parasites. but breathtaking views and cute little benches tucked in woodsy corners *almost* make me forget about how much that sucks. not really though. it's vile. fuck that.
author: Mary V.

description: This was the first park I took my puppy to.  It's a great place to get your puppy socialized to other dogs and people, as there are a lot of great dog walkers that go here.  It is also where I met my current dog walker.  It is a safe place to have your dog off-leash for the first time as it is away from the street and busy roads.  I would give this park 5 stars but I can't because of the following two reasons.  One, there is poison oak here as I have so unfortunately discovered!  So try to keep an eye on your dog when they run off into the sections of dense foliage around the paved trail.  The oil from the poison oak can rub onto their fur, and then onto you and everywhere else the dog rubs up against.  Two, I was told by a friend, and I quote: "people come here to f**k, so be on the watch out for what your dog picks up"; which would explain the condom that came out of my dogs bum a few weeks ago....  Well, at least I know people here are having safe sex, ha ha!
author: Billy B.

description: Great off leash park.  You can forget that you'er in a city in this park.
author: Dave S.

description: Best park in the city! I have a Siberian Husky who loves to run, but has no fear of cars, and this is one of the only places in the city where I can let him off leash to run like a mad man. The whole walk is beautiful. There are many paths to choose from, some more of a workout than others, but the end result (the top of the hill) is always the same and beautiful. This has to be one of the best views in the city. As for Prima D.'s review, It must be tough to have such a crappy attitude towards everything that you can't even appreciate the beauty that's right in front of you. I am in this park every day, sometimes twice a day, and I have never seen anyone doing drugs or "needles and little bags filled with white powder" (Jennifer S.). And I don't think peeing on the stairs is doing anything to help the scenery of the park, or the enjoyment of others. For all of you newcomers, please don't listen to people like Prima D and Jennifer S, and go check it out for yourself, you won't be dissapointed (unless you don't like dogs, there are always a lot of well behaved dogs running around).
author: michele k.

description: Nice park to stroll in. I sometimes like to walk through it when I need some cheering up. The view is nice on the way up, although you wont have a view at the top because of the trees. As many places are in San Francisco, it is very hilly, and there is lots of noise from the traffic near the bottom.
author: Tedster H.
